comment_text.mn94:1.1: As usual, the lack of mention of the Buddha at the start suggests that this sutta is set after his passing away, a detail confirmed at the end. This sutta attests to the continued influence of Buddhism among the wealthy and influential as they adapted to the new realities after the Buddha’s passing.
comment_text.mn94:1.2: Neither monk nor monastery are mentioned elsewhere in early texts.
comment_text.mn94:2.1: This may be the Ghoṭamukha (“Beard-face”) of Kauṭilya’s Arthaśāstra 5.5.11. On the question of when a courtier should know that his king is displeased with him, a series of expert opinions are cited, each one bewilderingly cryptic. Ghoṭamukha says such a king is like a “wet cloth”. The key to these clues is provided in a particular story, which is deliberately unmentioned, presumably because of the delicacy of the subject.
comment_text.mn94:2.6: Ambho samaṇa (“worthy ascetic”) is a unique form of address.
comment_text.mn94:3.1: Udena takes care to ensure the setting is appropriate for a serious discussion.
comment_text.mn94:4.6: Ghoṭamukha was unfamiliar with the forms of address, admits he has never seen a mendicant, talks to Udena while he is walking meditation, and does not know when he should sit down. Udena, noticing his awkwardness, makes sure that Ghoṭamukha understands that he can engage in a conversation without impropriety.
comment_text.mn94:8.5: The commentary glosses sānuggahā with sakāraṇā, “with reason”.
comment_text.mn94:10.1: For details, see notes at MN 12:45.1, MN 27:11.1, and MN 51:8.1.
comment_text.mn94:33.1: The mention of the king of Aṅga is unique. Aṅga had been conquered by Bimbisāra long ago and became part of Magadha. There is a faint memory of a time when Rājagaha was a city of Aṅga (Ja 546:36.2), but Aṅga’s glory days were long past. Perhaps “king of Aṅga” was a title of the king of Magadha, or else of a vassal ruler. | Niccabhikkhā at Ja 398:4.1 refers to the daily offering of food to a yakkha, which must be the early meaning. But here and at SN 3.13:4.4 it refers to money.
comment_text.mn94:33.3: A kahāpaṇa is in the ballpark of a US dollar. At AN 10.46 the wages for an honest day’s work start at half a kahāpaṇa, which compares with the poverty line in modern India of 38 rupees/day or 48 US cents. The upper level income is a thousand kahāpaṇas per day, so Ghoṭamukha’s allowance made him a rich man.
comment_text.mn94:33.5: A vihāra was a “dwelling” in a monastery, not, as in later usage, an entire monastery.
comment_text.mn94:33.6: This reflects the central role of the new capital of Pāṭaliputta after the Buddha died (DN 16:1.28.7). Compare the similar offering at MN 52:16.1.

root_text.mn94:1.2: ekaṁ samayaṁ āyasmā udeno bārāṇasiyaṁ viharati khemiyambavane.
root_text.mn94:2.1: Tena kho pana samayena ghoṭamukho brāhmaṇo bārāṇasiṁ anuppatto hoti kenacideva karaṇīyena.
root_text.mn94:2.2: Atha kho ghoṭamukho brāhmaṇo jaṅghāvihāraṁ anucaṅkamamāno anuvicaramāno yena khemiyambavanaṁ tenupasaṅkami.
root_text.mn94:2.3: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā udeno abbhokāse caṅkamati.
root_text.mn94:2.4: Atha kho ghoṭamukho brāhmaṇo yenāyasmā udeno tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā udenena saddhiṁ sammodi.
root_text.mn94:2.5: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā āyasmantaṁ udenaṁ caṅkamantaṁ anucaṅkamamāno evamāha:
root_text.mn94:2.8: Tañca kho bhavantarūpānaṁ vā adassanā, yo vā panettha dhammo”ti.
root_text.mn94:3.1: Evaṁ vutte, āyasmā udeno caṅkamā orohitvā vihāraṁ pavisitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
root_text.mn94:3.2: Ghoṭamukhopi kho brāhmaṇo caṅkamā orohitvā vihāraṁ pavisitvā ekamantaṁ aṭṭhāsi.
root_text.mn94:3.3: Ekamantaṁ ṭhitaṁ kho ghoṭamukhaṁ brāhmaṇaṁ āyasmā udeno etadavoca:
root_text.mn94:3.6: “Etadeva kho pana mayaṁ bhoto udenassa āgamayamānā nisīdāma.
root_text.mn94:3.7: Kathañhi nāma mādiso pubbe animantito āsane nisīditabbaṁ maññeyyā”ti?
root_text.mn94:4.1: Atha kho ghoṭamukho brāhmaṇo aññataraṁ nīcaṁ āsanaṁ gahetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi.
root_text.mn94:4.2: Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho ghoṭamukho brāhmaṇo āyasmantaṁ udenaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn94:4.5: Tañca kho bhavantarūpānaṁ vā adassanā, yo vā panettha dhammo”ti.
root_text.mn94:4.6: “Sace kho pana me tvaṁ, brāhmaṇa, anuññeyyaṁ anujāneyyāsi, paṭikkositabbañca paṭikkoseyyāsi; yassa ca pana me bhāsitassa atthaṁ na jāneyyāsi, mamaṁyeva tattha uttari paṭipuccheyyāsi:
root_text.mn94:4.7: ‘idaṁ, bho udena, kathaṁ, imassa kvattho’ti? Evaṁ katvā siyā no ettha kathāsallāpo”ti.
root_text.mn94:4.8: “Anuññeyyaṁ khvāhaṁ bhoto udenassa anujānissāmi, paṭikkositabbañca paṭikkosissāmi; yassa ca panāhaṁ bhoto udenassa bhāsitassa atthaṁ na jānissāmi, bhavantaṁyeva tattha udenaṁ uttari paṭipucchissāmi: ‘idaṁ, bho udena, kathaṁ, imassa kvattho’ti? Evaṁ katvā hotu no ettha kathāsallāpo”ti.
root_text.mn94:5.3: Idha, brāhmaṇa, ekacco puggalo attantapo hoti attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
root_text.mn94:5.4: Idha pana, brāhmaṇa, ekacco puggalo parantapo hoti paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
root_text.mn94:5.5: Idha pana, brāhmaṇa, ekacco puggalo attantapo ca hoti attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto parantapo ca paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
root_text.mn94:5.6: Idha pana, brāhmaṇa, ekacco puggalo nevattantapo hoti nāttaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto, na parantapo na paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
root_text.mn94:5.7: So anattantapo aparantapo diṭṭheva dhamme nicchāto nibbuto sītībhūto sukhappaṭisaṁvedī brahmabhūtena attanā viharati.
root_text.mn94:5.8: Imesaṁ, brāhmaṇa, catunnaṁ puggalānaṁ katamo te puggalo cittaṁ ārādhetī”ti?
root_text.mn94:5.9: “Yvāyaṁ, bho udena, puggalo attantapo attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto ayaṁ me puggalo cittaṁ nārādheti;
root_text.mn94:5.10: yopāyaṁ, bho udena, puggalo parantapo paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto ayampi me puggalo cittaṁ nārādheti;
root_text.mn94:5.11: yopāyaṁ, bho udena, puggalo attantapo ca attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto parantapo ca paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto ayampi me puggalo cittaṁ nārādheti;
root_text.mn94:5.12: yo ca kho ayaṁ, bho udena, puggalo nevattantapo nāttaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto na parantapo na paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto so anattantapo aparantapo diṭṭheva dhamme nicchāto nibbuto sītībhūto sukhappaṭisaṁvedī brahmabhūtena attanā viharati.
root_text.mn94:6.1: “Kasmā pana te, brāhmaṇa, ime tayo puggalā cittaṁ nārādhentī”ti?
root_text.mn94:6.2: “Yvāyaṁ, bho udena, puggalo attantapo attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto so attānaṁ sukhakāmaṁ dukkhapaṭikkūlaṁ ātāpeti paritāpeti;
root_text.mn94:6.3: iminā me ayaṁ puggalo cittaṁ nārādheti.
root_text.mn94:6.4: Yopāyaṁ, bho udena, puggalo parantapo paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto so paraṁ sukhakāmaṁ dukkhapaṭikkūlaṁ ātāpeti paritāpeti;
root_text.mn94:6.5: iminā me ayaṁ puggalo cittaṁ nārādheti.
root_text.mn94:6.6: Yopāyaṁ, bho udena, puggalo attantapo ca attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto parantapo ca paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto so attānañca parañca sukhakāmaṁ dukkhapaṭikkūlaṁ ātāpeti paritāpeti;
root_text.mn94:6.7: iminā me ayaṁ puggalo cittaṁ nārādheti.
root_text.mn94:6.8: Yo ca kho ayaṁ, bho udena, puggalo nevattantapo nāttaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto na parantapo na paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto so anattantapo aparantapo diṭṭheva dhamme nicchāto nibbuto sītībhūto sukhappaṭisaṁvedī brahmabhūtena attanā viharati, so attānañca parañca sukhakāmaṁ dukkhapaṭikkūlaṁ neva ātāpeti na paritāpeti;
root_text.mn94:6.9: iminā me ayaṁ puggalo cittaṁ ārādhetī”ti.
root_text.mn94:7.3: Idha, brāhmaṇa, ekaccā parisā sārattarattā maṇikuṇḍalesu puttabhariyaṁ pariyesati, dāsidāsaṁ pariyesati, khettavatthuṁ pariyesati, jātarūparajataṁ pariyesati.
root_text.mn94:7.4: Idha pana, brāhmaṇa, ekaccā parisā asārattarattā maṇikuṇḍalesu puttabhariyaṁ pahāya, dāsidāsaṁ pahāya, khettavatthuṁ pahāya, jātarūparajataṁ pahāya, agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajitā.
root_text.mn94:7.5: Svāyaṁ, brāhmaṇa, puggalo nevattantapo nāttaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto na parantapo na paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
root_text.mn94:7.6: So anattantapo aparantapo diṭṭheva dhamme nicchāto nibbuto sītībhūto sukhappaṭisaṁvedī brahmabhūtena attanā viharati.
root_text.mn94:7.7: Idha katamaṁ tvaṁ, brāhmaṇa, puggalaṁ katamāya parisāya bahulaṁ samanupassasi—
root_text.mn94:7.8: yā cāyaṁ parisā sārattarattā maṇikuṇḍalesu puttabhariyaṁ pariyesati dāsidāsaṁ pariyesati khettavatthuṁ pariyesati jātarūparajataṁ pariyesati, yā cāyaṁ parisā asārattarattā maṇikuṇḍalesu puttabhariyaṁ pahāya dāsidāsaṁ pahāya khettavatthuṁ pahāya jātarūparajataṁ pahāya agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajitā”ti?
root_text.mn94:7.9: “Yvāyaṁ, bho udena, puggalo nevattantapo nāttaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto na parantapo na paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto so anattantapo aparantapo diṭṭheva dhamme nicchāto nibbuto sītībhūto sukhappaṭisaṁvedī brahmabhūtena attanā viharati;
root_text.mn94:7.10: imāhaṁ puggalaṁ yāyaṁ parisā asārattarattā maṇikuṇḍalesu puttabhariyaṁ pahāya dāsidāsaṁ pahāya khettavatthuṁ pahāya jātarūparajataṁ pahāya agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajitā imissaṁ parisāyaṁ bahulaṁ samanupassāmī”ti.
root_text.mn94:8.1: “Idāneva kho pana te, brāhmaṇa, bhāsitaṁ: ‘mayaṁ evaṁ ājānāma—
root_text.mn94:8.4: Tañca kho bhavantarūpānaṁ vā adassanā, yo vā panettha dhammo’”ti.
root_text.mn94:8.5: “Addhā mesā, bho udena, sānuggahā vācā bhāsitā.
root_text.mn94:8.8: Evañca pana maṁ bhavaṁ udeno dhāretu.
root_text.mn94:8.9: Ye ca me bhotā udenena cattāro puggalā saṅkhittena vuttā vitthārena avibhattā, sādhu me bhavaṁ, udeno ime cattāro puggale vitthārena vibhajatu anukampaṁ upādāyā”ti.
root_text.mn94:9.1: “Tena hi, brāhmaṇa, suṇāhi, sādhukaṁ manasi karohi, bhāsissāmī”ti.
root_text.mn94:9.2: “Evaṁ, bho”ti kho ghoṭamukho brāhmaṇo āyasmato udenassa paccassosi.
root_text.mn94:10.2: Idha, brāhmaṇa, ekacco puggalo acelako hoti muttācāro hatthāpalekhano naehibhaddantiko natiṭṭhabhaddantiko, nābhihaṭaṁ na uddissakataṁ na nimantanaṁ sādiyati.
root_text.mn94:10.3: So na kumbhimukhā paṭiggaṇhāti, na kaḷopimukhā paṭiggaṇhāti, na eḷakamantaraṁ, na daṇḍamantaraṁ, na musalamantaraṁ, na dvinnaṁ bhuñjamānānaṁ, na gabbhiniyā, na pāyamānāya, na purisantaragatāya, na saṅkittīsu, na yattha sā upaṭṭhito hoti, na yattha makkhikā saṇḍasaṇḍacārinī, na macchaṁ na maṁsaṁ, na suraṁ na merayaṁ na thusodakaṁ pivati.
root_text.mn94:10.4: So ekāgāriko vā hoti ekālopiko, dvāgāriko vā hoti dvālopiko …pe… sattāgāriko vā hoti sattālopiko;
root_text.mn94:10.5: ekissāpi dattiyā yāpeti, dvīhipi dattīhi yāpeti …pe… sattahipi dattīhi yāpeti;
root_text.mn94:10.6: ekāhikampi āhāraṁ āhāreti, dvīhikampi āhāraṁ āhāreti …pe… sattāhikampi āhāraṁ āhāreti—iti evarūpaṁ addhamāsikaṁ pariyāyabhattabhojanānuyogamanuyutto viharati.
root_text.mn94:10.7: So sākabhakkho vā hoti, sāmākabhakkho vā hoti, nīvārabhakkho vā hoti, daddulabhakkho vā hoti, haṭabhakkho vā hoti, kaṇabhakkho vā hoti, ācāmabhakkho vā hoti, piññākabhakkho vā hoti, tiṇabhakkho vā hoti, gomayabhakkho vā hoti, vanamūlaphalāhāro yāpeti pavattaphalabhojī.
root_text.mn94:10.8: So sāṇānipi dhāreti, masāṇānipi dhāreti, chavadussānipi dhāreti, paṁsukūlānipi dhāreti, tirīṭānipi dhāreti, ajinampi dhāreti, ajinakkhipampi dhāreti, kusacīrampi dhāreti, vākacīrampi dhāreti, phalakacīrampi dhāreti, kesakambalampi dhāreti, vāḷakambalampi dhāreti, ulūkapakkhampi dhāreti;
root_text.mn94:10.14: iti evarūpaṁ anekavihitaṁ kāyassa ātāpanaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto viharati.
root_text.mn94:10.15: Ayaṁ vuccati, brāhmaṇa, puggalo attantapo attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
root_text.mn94:11.1: Katamo ca, brāhmaṇa, puggalo parantapo paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto?
root_text.mn94:11.2: Idha, brāhmaṇa, ekacco puggalo orabbhiko hoti sūkariko sākuṇiko māgaviko luddo macchaghātako coro coraghātako goghātako bandhanāgāriko—ye vā panaññepi keci kurūrakammantā.
root_text.mn94:11.3: Ayaṁ vuccati, brāhmaṇa, puggalo parantapo paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
root_text.mn94:12.1: Katamo ca, brāhmaṇa, puggalo attantapo ca attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto, parantapo ca paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto?
root_text.mn94:12.2: Idha, brāhmaṇa, ekacco puggalo rājā vā hoti khattiyo muddhāvasitto, brāhmaṇo vā mahāsālo.
root_text.mn94:12.3: So puratthimena nagarassa navaṁ santhāgāraṁ kārāpetvā kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kharājinaṁ nivāsetvā sappitelena kāyaṁ abbhañjitvā magavisāṇena piṭṭhiṁ kaṇḍuvamāno navaṁ santhāgāraṁ pavisati saddhiṁ mahesiyā brāhmaṇena ca purohitena.
root_text.mn94:12.4: So tattha anantarahitāya bhūmiyā haritupalittāya seyyaṁ kappeti.
root_text.mn94:12.5: Ekissāya gāviyā sarūpavacchāya yaṁ ekasmiṁ thane khīraṁ hoti tena rājā yāpeti, yaṁ dutiyasmiṁ thane khīraṁ hoti tena mahesī yāpeti, yaṁ tatiyasmiṁ thane khīraṁ hoti tena brāhmaṇo purohito yāpeti, yaṁ catutthasmiṁ thane khīraṁ hoti tena aggiṁ juhati, avasesena vacchako yāpeti.
root_text.mn94:12.7: ‘ettakā usabhā haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā vacchatarā haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā vacchatariyo haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā ajā haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā urabbhā haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā assā haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā rukkhā chijjantu yūpatthāya, ettakā dabbhā lūyantu barihisatthāyā’ti.
root_text.mn94:12.8: Yepissa te honti ‘dāsā’ti vā ‘pessā’ti vā ‘kammakarā’ti vā tepi daṇḍatajjitā bhayatajjitā assumukhā rudamānā parikammāni karonti.
root_text.mn94:12.9: Ayaṁ vuccati, brāhmaṇa, puggalo attantapo ca attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto, parantapo ca paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
root_text.mn94:13.1: Katamo ca, brāhmaṇa, puggalo nevattantapo nāttaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto, na parantapo na paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto;
root_text.mn94:13.2: so anattantapo aparantapo diṭṭheva dhamme nicchāto nibbuto sītībhūto sukhappaṭisaṁvedī brahmabhūtena attanā viharati?
root_text.mn94:14.1: Idha, brāhmaṇa, tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṁ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṁ buddho bhagavā.
root_text.mn94:14.2: So imaṁ lokaṁ sadevakaṁ samārakaṁ sabrahmakaṁ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṁ pajaṁ sadevamanussaṁ sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti.
root_text.mn94:14.3: So dhammaṁ deseti ādikalyāṇaṁ majjhekalyāṇaṁ pariyosānakalyāṇaṁ sātthaṁ sabyañjanaṁ, kevalaparipuṇṇaṁ parisuddhaṁ brahmacariyaṁ pakāseti.
root_text.mn94:15.1: Taṁ dhammaṁ suṇāti gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā aññatarasmiṁ vā kule paccājāto.
root_text.mn94:15.2: So taṁ dhammaṁ sutvā tathāgate saddhaṁ paṭilabhati.
root_text.mn94:15.3: So tena saddhāpaṭilābhena samannāgato iti paṭisañcikkhati:
root_text.mn94:15.5: Nayidaṁ sukaraṁ agāraṁ ajjhāvasatā ekantaparipuṇṇaṁ ekantaparisuddhaṁ saṅkhalikhitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ carituṁ.
root_text.mn94:15.6: Yannūnāhaṁ kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajeyyan’ti.
root_text.mn94:15.7: So aparena samayena appaṁ vā bhogakkhandhaṁ pahāya mahantaṁ vā bhogakkhandhaṁ pahāya, appaṁ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṁ pahāya mahantaṁ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṁ pahāya, kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajati.
root_text.mn94:15.8: So evaṁ pabbajito samāno bhikkhūnaṁ sikkhāsājīvasamāpanno pāṇātipātaṁ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti, nihitadaṇḍo nihitasattho lajjī dayāpanno sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī viharati.
root_text.mn94:16.1: Adinnādānaṁ pahāya adinnādānā paṭivirato hoti dinnādāyī dinnapāṭikaṅkhī. Athenena sucibhūtena attanā viharati.
root_text.mn94:16.2: Abrahmacariyaṁ pahāya brahmacārī hoti ārācārī virato methunā gāmadhammā.
root_text.mn94:16.3: Musāvādaṁ pahāya musāvādā paṭivirato hoti saccavādī saccasandho theto paccayiko avisaṁvādako lokassa.
root_text.mn94:16.4: Pisuṇaṁ vācaṁ pahāya pisuṇāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti; ito sutvā na amutra akkhātā imesaṁ bhedāya, amutra vā sutvā na imesaṁ akkhātā amūsaṁ bhedāya. Iti bhinnānaṁ vā sandhātā sahitānaṁ vā anuppadātā, samaggārāmo samaggarato samagganandī samaggakaraṇiṁ vācaṁ bhāsitā hoti.
root_text.mn94:16.5: Pharusaṁ vācaṁ pahāya pharusāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti. Yā sā vācā nelā kaṇṇasukhā pemanīyā hadayaṅgamā porī bahujanakantā bahujanamanāpā tathārūpiṁ vācaṁ bhāsitā hoti.
root_text.mn94:16.6: Samphappalāpaṁ pahāya samphappalāpā paṭivirato hoti, kālavādī bhūtavādī atthavādī dhammavādī vinayavādī, nidhānavatiṁ vācaṁ bhāsitā kālena sāpadesaṁ pariyantavatiṁ atthasaṁhitaṁ.
root_text.mn94:17.1: So santuṭṭho hoti kāyaparihārikena cīvarena, kucchiparihārikena piṇḍapātena. So yena yeneva pakkamati samādāyeva pakkamati.
root_text.mn94:17.2: Seyyathāpi nāma pakkhī sakuṇo yena yeneva ḍeti sapattabhārova ḍeti;
root_text.mn94:17.3: evameva bhikkhu santuṭṭho hoti kāyaparihārikena cīvarena, kucchiparihārikena piṇḍapātena. So yena yeneva pakkamati samādāyeva pakkamati.
root_text.mn94:17.4: So iminā ariyena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato ajjhattaṁ anavajjasukhaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti.
root_text.mn94:18.1: So cakkhunā rūpaṁ disvā na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī.
root_text.mn94:18.2: Yatvādhikaraṇamenaṁ cakkhundriyaṁ asaṁvutaṁ viharantaṁ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṁ tassa saṁvarāya paṭipajjati, rakkhati cakkhundriyaṁ, cakkhundriye saṁvaraṁ āpajjati.
root_text.mn94:18.7: manasā dhammaṁ viññāya na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī.
root_text.mn94:18.8: Yatvādhikaraṇamenaṁ manindriyaṁ asaṁvutaṁ viharantaṁ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṁ tassa saṁvarāya paṭipajjati, rakkhati manindriyaṁ, manindriye saṁvaraṁ āpajjati.
root_text.mn94:18.9: So iminā ariyena indriyasaṁvarena samannāgato ajjhattaṁ abyāsekasukhaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti.
root_text.mn94:19.1: So abhikkante paṭikkante sampajānakārī hoti, ālokite vilokite sampajānakārī hoti, samiñjite pasārite sampajānakārī hoti, saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇe sampajānakārī hoti, asite pīte khāyite sāyite sampajānakārī hoti, uccārapassāvakamme sampajānakārī hoti, gate ṭhite nisinne sutte jāgarite bhāsite tuṇhībhāve sampajānakārī hoti.
root_text.mn94:20.1: So iminā ca ariyena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato, imāya ca ariyāya santuṭṭhiyā samannāgato, iminā ca ariyena indriyasaṁvarena samannāgato, iminā ca ariyena satisampajaññena samannāgato
root_text.mn94:20.2: vivittaṁ senāsanaṁ bhajati araññaṁ rukkhamūlaṁ pabbataṁ kandaraṁ giriguhaṁ susānaṁ vanapatthaṁ abbhokāsaṁ palālapuñjaṁ.
root_text.mn94:21.1: So pacchābhattaṁ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto nisīdati pallaṅkaṁ ābhujitvā, ujuṁ kāyaṁ paṇidhāya, parimukhaṁ satiṁ upaṭṭhapetvā.
root_text.mn94:21.2: So abhijjhaṁ loke pahāya vigatābhijjhena cetasā viharati, abhijjhāya cittaṁ parisodheti;
root_text.mn94:21.3: byāpādapadosaṁ pahāya abyāpannacitto viharati sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī, byāpādapadosā cittaṁ parisodheti;
root_text.mn94:21.4: thinamiddhaṁ pahāya vigatathinamiddho viharati ālokasaññī sato sampajāno, thinamiddhā cittaṁ parisodheti;
root_text.mn94:21.5: uddhaccakukkuccaṁ pahāya anuddhato viharati ajjhattaṁ vūpasantacitto, uddhaccakukkuccā cittaṁ parisodheti;
root_text.mn94:21.6: vicikicchaṁ pahāya tiṇṇavicikiccho viharati akathaṅkathī kusalesu dhammesu, vicikicchāya cittaṁ parisodheti.
root_text.mn94:22.1: So ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe
root_text.mn94:22.2: vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn94:23.1: Vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā ajjhattaṁ sampasādanaṁ cetaso ekodibhāvaṁ avitakkaṁ avicāraṁ samādhijaṁ pītisukhaṁ dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn94:24.1: Pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati sato ca sampajāno, sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṁvedeti, yaṁ taṁ ariyā ācikkhanti: ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn94:25.1: Sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā, pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā, adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn94:26.1: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.
root_text.mn94:26.2: So anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṁsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi, anekepi saṁvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe: ‘amutrāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto; so tato cuto amutra udapādiṁ; tatrāpāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto; so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati.
root_text.mn94:27.1: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte sattānaṁ cutūpapātañāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.
root_text.mn94:27.2: So dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti: ‘ime vata bhonto sattā kāyaduccaritena samannāgatā …pe… ariyānaṁ upavādakā micchādiṭṭhikā micchādiṭṭhikammasamādānā, te kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapannā. Ime vā pana bhonto sattā kāyasucaritena samannāgatā …pe… ariyānaṁ anupavādakā sammādiṭṭhikā sammādiṭṭhikammasamādānā, te kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapannā’ti. Iti dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti.
root_text.mn94:28.1: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte āsavānaṁ khayañāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.
root_text.mn94:28.2: So ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti;
root_text.mn94:28.3: ‘ime āsavā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ āsavasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ āsavanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.
root_text.mn94:29.1: Tassa evaṁ jānato evaṁ passato kāmāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, bhavāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, avijjāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati.
root_text.mn94:29.3: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
root_text.mn94:30.1: Ayaṁ vuccati, brāhmaṇa, puggalo nevattantapo nāttaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto, na parantapo na paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
root_text.mn94:30.2: So anattantapo aparantapo diṭṭheva dhamme nicchāto nibbuto sītībhūto sukhappaṭisaṁvedī brahmabhūtena attanā viharatī”ti.
root_text.mn94:31.1: Evaṁ vutte, ghoṭamukho brāhmaṇo āyasmantaṁ udenaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn94:31.3: Seyyathāpi, bho udena, nikkujjitaṁ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṁ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṁ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṁ dhāreyya ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṁ bhotā udenena anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
root_text.mn94:31.4: Esāhaṁ bhavantaṁ udenaṁ saraṇaṁ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
root_text.mn94:31.5: Upāsakaṁ maṁ bhavaṁ udeno dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṁ saraṇaṁ gatan”ti.
root_text.mn94:32.1: “Mā kho maṁ tvaṁ, brāhmaṇa, saraṇaṁ agamāsi.
root_text.mn94:32.2: Tameva bhagavantaṁ saraṇaṁ gacchāhi yamahaṁ saraṇaṁ gato”ti.
root_text.mn94:32.3: “Kahaṁ pana, bho udena, etarahi so bhavaṁ gotamo viharati arahaṁ sammāsambuddho”ti?
root_text.mn94:32.4: “Parinibbuto kho, brāhmaṇa, etarahi so bhagavā arahaṁ sammāsambuddho”ti.
root_text.mn94:32.5: “Sacepi mayaṁ, bho udena, suṇeyyāma taṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ dasasu yojanesu, dasapi mayaṁ yojanāni gaccheyyāma taṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ dassanāya arahantaṁ sammāsambuddhaṁ.
root_text.mn94:32.6: Sacepi mayaṁ, bho udena, suṇeyyāma taṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ vīsatiyā yojanesu …
root_text.mn94:32.9: paññāsāya yojanesu, paññāsampi mayaṁ yojanāni gaccheyyāma taṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ dassanāya arahantaṁ sammāsambuddhaṁ.
root_text.mn94:32.10: Yojanasate cepi mayaṁ, bho udena, suṇeyyāma taṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ, yojanasatampi mayaṁ gaccheyyāma taṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ dassanāya arahantaṁ sammāsambuddhaṁ.
root_text.mn94:32.11: Yato ca kho, bho udena, parinibbuto so bhavaṁ gotamo, parinibbutampi mayaṁ taṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ saraṇaṁ gacchāma dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
root_text.mn94:32.12: Upāsakaṁ maṁ bhavaṁ udeno dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṁ saraṇaṁ gataṁ.
root_text.mn94:33.1: Atthi ca me, bho udena, aṅgarājā devasikaṁ niccabhikkhaṁ dadāti, tato ahaṁ bhoto udenassa ekaṁ niccabhikkhaṁ dadāmī”ti.
root_text.mn94:33.2: “Kiṁ pana te, brāhmaṇa, aṅgarājā devasikaṁ niccabhikkhaṁ dadātī”ti?
root_text.mn94:33.4: “Na kho no, brāhmaṇa, kappati jātarūparajataṁ paṭiggahetun”ti.
root_text.mn94:33.5: “Sace taṁ bhoto udenassa na kappati vihāraṁ bhoto udenassa kārāpessāmī”ti.
root_text.mn94:33.6: “Sace kho me tvaṁ, brāhmaṇa, vihāraṁ, kārāpetukāmo, pāṭaliputte saṅghassa upaṭṭhānasālaṁ kārāpehī”ti.
root_text.mn94:33.7: “Imināpāhaṁ bhoto udenassa bhiyyoso mattāya attamano abhiraddho yaṁ maṁ bhavaṁ udeno saṅghe dāne samādapeti.
root_text.mn94:33.8: Esāhaṁ, bho udena, etissā ca niccabhikkhāya aparāya ca niccabhikkhāya pāṭaliputte saṅghassa upaṭṭhānasālaṁ kārāpessāmī”ti.
root_text.mn94:33.9: Atha kho ghoṭamukho brāhmaṇo etissā ca niccabhikkhāya aparāya ca niccabhikkhāya pāṭaliputte saṅghassa upaṭṭhānasālaṁ kārāpesi.

translation_text.mn94:1.2: At one time Venerable Udena was staying near Varanasi in the Khemiya Mango Grove.
translation_text.mn94:2.1: Now at that time the brahmin Ghoṭamukha had arrived at Varanasi on some business.
translation_text.mn94:2.2: Then as he was going for a walk he went to the Khemiya Mango Grove.
translation_text.mn94:2.3: At that time Venerable Udena was walking mindfully in the open air.
translation_text.mn94:2.4: Ghoṭamukha approached and exchanged greetings with him.
translation_text.mn94:2.6: “Worthy ascetic, there is no such thing as a principled renunciate life;
translation_text.mn94:2.8: Yet I have not seen honorable ones such as yourself, or a relevant teaching.”
translation_text.mn94:3.1: When he said this, Udena stepped down from the walking path, entered his dwelling, and sat down on the seat spread out.
translation_text.mn94:3.2: Ghoṭamukha also stepped down from the walking path and entered the dwelling, where he stood to one side.
translation_text.mn94:3.6: “I was just waiting for you to sit down.
translation_text.mn94:3.7: For how on earth could one such as I presume to sit first without being invited?”
translation_text.mn94:4.1: Then he took a low seat and sat to one side,
translation_text.mn94:4.3: “Worthy ascetic, there is no such thing as a principled renunciate life;
translation_text.mn94:4.5: Yet I have not seen honorable ones such as yourself, or a relevant teaching.”
translation_text.mn94:4.6: “Brahmin, we can discuss this. But only if you grant what should be granted, and reject what should be rejected. And if you ask me the meaning of anything you don’t understand, saying:
translation_text.mn94:4.7: ‘Sir, why is this? What does that mean?’”
translation_text.mn94:4.8: “Let us discuss this. I will do as you say.”
translation_text.mn94:5.1: “Brahmin, these four individuals are found in the world.
translation_text.mn94:5.3: One individual mortifies themselves, committed to the practice of mortifying themselves.
translation_text.mn94:5.4: One individual mortifies others, committed to the practice of mortifying others.
translation_text.mn94:5.5: One individual mortifies themselves and others, committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others.
translation_text.mn94:5.6: One individual doesn’t mortify either themselves or others, committed to the practice of not mortifying themselves or others.
translation_text.mn94:5.7: They live without wishes in this very life, quenched, cooled, experiencing bliss, with self become divine.
translation_text.mn94:5.8: Which one of these four individuals do you like the sound of?”
translation_text.mn94:5.9: “Sir, I don’t like the sound of the first three individuals.
translation_text.mn94:5.13: I only like the sound of the last individual, who doesn’t mortify either themselves or others.”
translation_text.mn94:6.1: “But why don’t you like the sound of those three individuals?”
translation_text.mn94:6.2: “Sir, the individual who mortifies themselves does so even though they want to be happy and recoil from pain.
translation_text.mn94:6.3: That’s why I don’t like the sound of that individual.
translation_text.mn94:6.4: The individual who mortifies others does so even though others want to be happy and recoil from pain.
translation_text.mn94:6.5: That’s why I don’t like the sound of that individual.
translation_text.mn94:6.6: The individual who mortifies themselves and others does so even though both themselves and others want to be happy and recoil from pain.
translation_text.mn94:6.7: That’s why I don’t like the sound of that individual.
translation_text.mn94:6.8: The individual who doesn’t mortify either themselves or others—living without wishes, quenched, cooled, experiencing bliss, with self become divine—does not torment themselves or others, both of whom want to be happy and recoil from pain.
translation_text.mn94:6.9: That’s why I like the sound of that individual.”
translation_text.mn94:7.1: “There are, brahmin, these two groups of people.
translation_text.mn94:7.3: There’s one group of people who, being obsessed with jeweled earrings, seeks partners and children, male and female bondservants, fields and lands, and gold and currency.
translation_text.mn94:7.4: And there’s another group of people who, not being obsessed with jeweled earrings, has given up partner and children, male and female bondservants, fields and lands, and gold and currency, and goes forth from the lay life to homelessness.
translation_text.mn94:7.5: Now, brahmin, that individual who doesn’t mortify either themselves or others—
translation_text.mn94:7.7: in which of these two groups of people do you usually find such an individual?”
translation_text.mn94:7.9: “I usually find such an individual in
translation_text.mn94:7.10: the group that has gone forth from the lay life to homelessness.”
translation_text.mn94:8.1: “Just now I understood you to say:
translation_text.mn94:8.2: ‘Worthy ascetic, there is no such thing as a principled renunciate life;
translation_text.mn94:8.4: Yet I have not seen honorable ones such as yourself, or a relevant teaching.”
translation_text.mn94:8.5: “Well, I obviously had my reasons for saying that, master Udena.
translation_text.mn94:8.6: But there is such a thing as a principled renunciate life.
translation_text.mn94:8.8: and that’s how you should remember me.
translation_text.mn94:8.9: Now, these four individuals that you’ve spoken of in a brief summary: please explain them to me in detail, out of sympathy.”
translation_text.mn94:9.1: “Well then, brahmin, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
translation_text.mn94:10.1: “What individual mortifies themselves, committed to the practice of mortifying themselves?
translation_text.mn94:10.2: It’s when an individual goes naked, ignoring conventions. They lick their hands, and don’t come or wait when called. They don’t consent to food brought to them, or food prepared on their behalf, or an invitation for a meal.
translation_text.mn94:10.3: They don’t receive anything from a pot or bowl; or from someone who keeps sheep, or who has a weapon or a shovel in their home; or where a couple is eating; or where there is a woman who is pregnant, breastfeeding, or who lives with a man; or where there’s a hound waiting or flies buzzing. They accept no fish or meat or beer or wine, and drink no fermented gruel.
translation_text.mn94:10.4: They go to just one house for alms, taking just one mouthful, or two houses and two mouthfuls, up to seven houses and seven mouthfuls.
translation_text.mn94:10.5: They feed on one saucer a day, two saucers a day, up to seven saucers a day.
translation_text.mn94:10.6: They eat once a day, once every second day, up to once a week, and so on, even up to once a fortnight. They live committed to the practice of eating food at set intervals.
translation_text.mn94:10.7: They eat herbs, millet, wild rice, poor rice, water lettuce, rice bran, scum from boiling rice, sesame flour, grass, or cow dung. They survive on forest roots and fruits, or eating fallen fruit.
translation_text.mn94:10.8: They wear robes of sunn hemp, mixed hemp, corpse-wrapping cloth, rags, lodh tree bark, antelope hide (whole or in strips), kusa grass, bark, wood-chips, human hair, horse-tail hair, or owls’ wings.
translation_text.mn94:10.9: They tear out their hair and beard, committed to this practice.
translation_text.mn94:10.10: They constantly stand, turning down seats.
translation_text.mn94:10.11: They squat, committed to the endeavor of squatting.
translation_text.mn94:10.12: They lie on a mat of thorns, making a mat of thorns their bed.
translation_text.mn94:10.13: They’re devoted to ritual bathing three times a day, including at dusk.
translation_text.mn94:10.14: And so they live committed to practicing these various ways of mortifying and tormenting the body.
translation_text.mn94:10.15: This is called an individual who mortifies themselves, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves.
translation_text.mn94:11.1: And what individual mortifies others, committed to the practice of mortifying others?
translation_text.mn94:11.2: It’s when an individual is a slaughterer of sheep, pigs, poultry, or deer, a hunter or fisher, a bandit, an executioner, a butcher of cattle, a jailer, or has some other cruel livelihood.
translation_text.mn94:11.3: This is called an individual who mortifies others, being committed to the practice of mortifying others.
translation_text.mn94:12.1: And what individual mortifies themselves and others, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others?
translation_text.mn94:12.2: It’s when an individual is an anointed aristocratic king or a well-to-do brahmin.
translation_text.mn94:12.3: He has a new ceremonial hall built to the east of the citadel. He shaves off his hair and beard, dresses in a rough antelope hide, and smears his body with ghee and oil. Scratching his back with antlers, he enters the hall with his chief queen and the brahmin high priest.
translation_text.mn94:12.4: There he lies on the bare ground strewn with grass.
translation_text.mn94:12.5: The king feeds on the milk from one teat of a cow that has a calf of the same color. The chief queen feeds on the milk from the second teat. The brahmin high priest feeds on the milk from the third teat. The milk from the fourth teat is served to the sacred flame. The calf feeds on the leftovers.
translation_text.mn94:12.7: ‘Slaughter this many bulls, bullocks, heifers, goats, rams, and horses for the sacrifice! Fell this many trees and reap this much grass for the sacrificial equipment!’
translation_text.mn94:12.8: His bondservants, servants, and workers do their jobs under threat of punishment and danger, weeping with tearful faces.
translation_text.mn94:12.9: This is called an individual who mortifies themselves and others, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others.
translation_text.mn94:13.1: And what individual doesn’t mortify either themselves or others, committed to the practice of not mortifying themselves or others,
translation_text.mn94:13.2: living without wishes in this very life, quenched, cooled, experiencing bliss, with self become divine?
translation_text.mn94:14.1: It’s when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.
translation_text.mn94:14.2: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
translation_text.mn94:14.3: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
translation_text.mn94:15.1: A householder hears that teaching, or a householder’s child, or someone reborn in a good family.
translation_text.mn94:15.2: They gain faith in the Realized One,
translation_text.mn94:15.4: ‘Life at home is cramped and dirty, life gone forth is wide open.
translation_text.mn94:15.5: It’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
translation_text.mn94:15.6: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’
translation_text.mn94:15.7: After some time they give up a large or small fortune, and a large or small family circle. They shave off hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
translation_text.mn94:15.8: Once they’ve gone forth, they take up the training and livelihood of the mendicants. They give up killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword. They’re scrupulous and kind, living full of sympathy for all living beings.
translation_text.mn94:16.1: They give up stealing. They take only what’s given, and expect only what’s given. They keep themselves clean by not thieving.
translation_text.mn94:16.2: They give up unchastity. They are chaste, set apart, avoiding the vulgar act of sex.
translation_text.mn94:16.3: They give up lying. They speak the truth and stick to the truth. They’re honest and dependable, and don’t trick the world with their words.
translation_text.mn94:16.4: They give up divisive speech. They don’t repeat in one place what they heard in another so as to divide people against each other. Instead, they reconcile those who are divided and support those who are united, delighting in harmony, loving harmony, speaking words that promote harmony.
translation_text.mn94:16.5: They give up harsh speech. They speak in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable and agreeable to the people.
translation_text.mn94:16.6: They give up talking nonsense. Their words are timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. They say things at the right time which are valuable, reasonable, succinct, and beneficial.
translation_text.mn94:16.7: They refrain from injuring plants and seeds.
translation_text.mn94:16.8: They eat in one part of the day, abstaining from eating at night and food at the wrong time.
translation_text.mn94:16.9: They refrain from seeing shows of dancing, singing, and music .
translation_text.mn94:16.10: They refrain from attiring and adorning themselves with garlands, fragrance, and makeup.
translation_text.mn94:16.11: They refrain from high and luxurious beds.
translation_text.mn94:16.12: They refrain from receiving gold and currency,
translation_text.mn94:16.21: They refrain from running errands and messages;
translation_text.mn94:16.25: mutilation, murder, abduction, banditry, plunder, and violence.
translation_text.mn94:17.1: They’re content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things.
translation_text.mn94:17.2: They’re like a bird: wherever it flies, wings are its only burden.
translation_text.mn94:17.3: In the same way, a mendicant is content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things.
translation_text.mn94:17.4: When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, they experience a blameless happiness inside themselves.
translation_text.mn94:18.1: When they see a sight with their eyes, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
translation_text.mn94:18.2: If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of sight, and achieving its restraint.
translation_text.mn94:18.3: When they hear a sound with their ears …
translation_text.mn94:18.4: When they smell an odor with their nose …
translation_text.mn94:18.5: When they taste a flavor with their tongue …
translation_text.mn94:18.6: When they feel a touch with their body …
translation_text.mn94:18.7: When they know an idea with their mind, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
translation_text.mn94:18.8: If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of mind, and achieving its restraint.
translation_text.mn94:18.9: When they have this noble sense restraint, they experience an unsullied bliss inside themselves.
translation_text.mn94:19.1: They act with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.
translation_text.mn94:20.1: When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, this noble contentment, this noble sense restraint, and this noble mindfulness and situational awareness,
translation_text.mn94:20.2: they frequent a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
translation_text.mn94:21.1: After the meal, they return from almsround, sit down cross-legged, set their body straight, and establish mindfulness in their presence.
translation_text.mn94:21.2: Giving up covetousness for the world, they meditate with a heart rid of covetousness, cleansing the mind of covetousness.
translation_text.mn94:21.3: Giving up ill will and malevolence, they meditate with a mind rid of ill will, full of sympathy for all living beings, cleansing the mind of ill will.
translation_text.mn94:21.4: Giving up dullness and drowsiness, they meditate with a mind rid of dullness and drowsiness, perceiving light, mindful and aware, cleansing the mind of dullness and drowsiness.
translation_text.mn94:21.5: Giving up restlessness and remorse, they meditate without restlessness, their mind peaceful inside, cleansing the mind of restlessness and remorse.
translation_text.mn94:21.6: Giving up doubt, they meditate having gone beyond doubt, not undecided about skillful qualities, cleansing the mind of doubt.
translation_text.mn94:22.1: They give up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom.
translation_text.mn94:22.2: Then, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.mn94:23.1: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.mn94:24.1: And with the fading away of rapture, they enter and remain in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
translation_text.mn94:25.1: With the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
translation_text.mn94:26.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward recollection of past lives.
translation_text.mn94:26.2: They recollect many kinds of past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
translation_text.mn94:27.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.
translation_text.mn94:27.2: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds: ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They denounced the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never denounced the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.
translation_text.mn94:28.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
translation_text.mn94:28.2: They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
translation_text.mn94:28.3: They truly understand: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’.
translation_text.mn94:29.1: Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
translation_text.mn94:29.2: When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
translation_text.mn94:29.3: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’
translation_text.mn94:30.1: This is called an individual who neither mortifies themselves or others, being committed to the practice of not mortifying themselves or others.
translation_text.mn94:30.2: They live without wishes in this very life, quenched, cooled, experiencing bliss, with self become divine.”
translation_text.mn94:31.1: When he had spoken, Ghoṭamukha said to him,
translation_text.mn94:31.3: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, the worthy Udena has made the teaching clear in many ways.
translation_text.mn94:31.4: I go for refuge to the worthy Udena, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
translation_text.mn94:31.5: From this day forth, may the worthy Udena remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
translation_text.mn94:32.1: “Brahmin, don’t go for refuge to me.
translation_text.mn94:32.2: You should go for refuge to that same Blessed One to whom I have gone for refuge.”
translation_text.mn94:32.3: “But worthy Udena, where is the Blessed One at present, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha?”
translation_text.mn94:32.4: “Brahmin, the Buddha has already become fully quenched.”
translation_text.mn94:32.5: “Worthy Udena, if I heard that the Buddha was within ten leagues, or twenty, or even up to a hundred leagues away, I’d go a hundred leagues to see him.
translation_text.mn94:32.11: But since the Buddha has become fully quenched, I go for refuge to that fully quenched Buddha, to the teaching, and to the Saṅgha.
translation_text.mn94:32.12: From this day forth, may the worthy Udena remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.
translation_text.mn94:33.1: Worthy Udena, the king of Aṅga gives me a regular daily allowance. I will give you one portion of that.”
translation_text.mn94:33.2: “But brahmin, what does the king of Aṅga give you as a regular daily allowance?”
translation_text.mn94:33.4: “It’s not proper for us to receive gold and currency.”
translation_text.mn94:33.5: “If that’s not proper, I will have a dwelling built for the worthy Udena.”
translation_text.mn94:33.6: “If you want to build me a dwelling, then build an assembly hall for the Saṅgha at Pāṭaliputta.”
translation_text.mn94:33.7: “Now I’m even more delighted and satisfied with the worthy Udena, since he encourages me to give to the Saṅgha.
translation_text.mn94:33.8: So with this allowance and another one I will have an assembly hall built for the Saṅgha at Pāṭaliputta.”
translation_text.mn94:33.9: And so he had that hall built.
translation_text.mn94:33.10: And these days it’s called the “Ghoṭamukhī”.

variant_text.mn94:32.5: Sacepi → sace (bj, pts1ed); sace hi (sya-all, km)
variant_text.mn94:32.10: Yojanasate cepi → yojanasatepi (bj, sya-all, km, pts1ed)
